positive.review:
In just 12 hours, I have determined this is the best WW2 RTS I have played since Blitzkrieg. Tons of fun playing the dynamic conquest game mode. Finish the tutorials, watch/read a few tips and tricks guides, and you will be set!

50 hour update: I still enjoy what this game has to offer. Like other reviews state, the AI is a little clunky, but nothing that really distracts me, or that I can't account for. The dynamic conquest and campaign is where is spend most of my time playing, because I haven't really desired more.

Here are some tips that changed the game up for me:
[olist]
     [*] when entrenching, use shift to set them all up without having to click multiple times, and use k to disband the squad so they stay with their foxhole
     [*] when not mobilized, get out of your supply vehicles, this will keep them safe(er) from the enemy. 
     [*] Your units will run out of ammo before they run out of gas. 
     [*] Infantry stats matter, understand them.
     [*] When playing dynamic conquest, you can loot and use equipment left on the battlefield in later matches, or sell it to afford more of your own. Save a tank crew for your final deployment so you can go around to repair.
[/olist]

This game only recently came to my attention, quite a while after its release — which is surprising, since I’ve always loved games set during World War II.

In my opinion, I’ve played almost every title that explores this theme, and this one might be among the very best. The fact that it’s a simulation and also allows you to control any unit directly in a quasi–first-person view adds tremendously to the overall experience. The landscapes, the level of detail, and all the little touches the developers paid attention to are simply fantastic. For example, the way soldiers react when they’re hit — how they fall, the realism of the animations — may seem like a small thing, but it greatly enhances immersion.

I definitely recommend it — whether for the mission mode or the practically endless research-based conquest and defense gameplay.

If I could suggest one improvement, it would be to allow players to preview units or vehicles in the research tree before unlocking them — like seeing the size of a squad or the layout of a tank. Maybe there’s a way to do that and I just haven’t figured it out yet.

Another great addition would be if soldiers could receive medals or distinctions as their XP and rank increase, or if there were a main commander character leading the troops who could earn unique decorations — that would make the experience truly next level.

In short, I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys deep and strategic WWII simulations!

I'm mainly a combat flight simmer.  I've also put a good bit of time into FPS games.  This game is my first foray into the tactical RTS genre (unless you count old board games from Avalon Hill as a kid).  That's some of my background fyi.  But if you're a lover of WW2 history like me, and/or games in this genre, I can't recommend Gates of Hell: Ostfront and its DLC's highly enough!  I've found it VERY challenging, but equally addictive!  (1000 hours invested now, in ~2 years!).  I've played almost no multiplayer - only 1 story mission with a friend, so far.  It was super fun, & far easier to manage all the assets.  I plan to do a LOT more COOP mode in this game.  I suck when lots of micro'ing is required, so I'd do poorly against most human players.   But If you want accuracy, numbers, and interaction - which the game delivers in spades - then the micro is just a necessary evil.  I love the historical battles they depict in the campaigns (even though they're hard for me to win).  But I think Conquest is my favorite mode right now.  I'm able to beat the 'heroic' level AI most of the time now, but I still lose some too.  Some people complain there are too few Conquest maps and I'll concede we could use more. But I believe the devs will provide more over time based on their outstanding track record of free updates & improvements.  Regardless of that, their open modding format means if you really tire of all the existing Conquest maps, you can just start using some of the excellent mods that offer them (along with more factions, other time periods, etc., etc.). That's what I'll do if needed.  In short I have nothing but very high praise for the team at Barbwire.  THANK YOU for a fabulous piece of work, guys!!  Looking forward to "Finest Hour!"

Call to Arms: Ostfront is exactly the evolution I always hoped to see from the classic Men of War series. As someone who has spent countless hours playing every MoW title, I can confidently say that Ostfront feels like a true step forward modernized, smarter, and more dynamic in every sense.

One of the standout improvements is the AI. Gone are the days of soldiers running into gunfire like they’re eager to meet the afterlife. Units behave with a level of intelligence that genuinely changes the flow of battle. They take cover intuitively, flank with purpose, and respond to threats with a situational awareness that makes every engagement feel intense and believable. Their use of support equipment and emplacements make them a lot more difficult to fight against and work around. It’s easily one of the biggest upgrades over Men of War and a major reason the game feels so fresh. Also the first person ability with direct controlling units while a bit gimmicky can be quite useful in some situations where line of sight is important and can be quite fun playing as a individual soldier.  

And then there are the dynamic campaigns, my absolute favourite addition. Each mission feels alive, with shifting objectives, changing battlefronts, and the sense that your decisions impact a larger campaign map. No two playthroughs feel the same. The way the game blends strategic planning with boots-on-the-ground direct control is just incredibly satisfying. I genuinely love diving into these campaigns; they keep me hooked for hours at a time.

Overall, Call to Arms: Ostfront is more than just a follow-up to Men of War, it’s an improvement in nearly every area. Better AI, deeper gameplay, more replayability, and a modern polish that breathes new life into the genre. I absolutely love what the developers have done here, and I can’t wait to sink even more time into its dynamic battlefields and for the new British faction update coming soon!

It's an amazing game developed by devs that obviously love what they're doing. The AI is not the smartest, but the CPU AI is by design smarter than yours (or you'd just lean back and watch your AI do your work for you). Small annoyances here and there, but only detectable once you develop an obsession and put in hundreds of hours into the game ("why can I do this with [this vehicle] but not with [this other vehicle], type of annoyances). 

The Discord channel is great where you can report bugs (which are addressed in 99% of the cases, unless it's a bug introduced by the game engine, which may take longer to address), and suggest new features (but be prepared to make a case for why you want a specific unit/weapon/vehicle introduced, and oftentimes to other more knowledgeable community members with severe WW2 autism), etc. Modding is limited by the engine but there are amazing community modders out there whose mods have eventually made it into the core game. I wish they could work more on the Conquest Game mode a bit more, but the devs have made meaningful strides there as well. 

The game can trigger tons of emotions: anxiety, despair, victory-induced euphoria, adrenaline kicks, and pure satisfaction, and the occasional rage quitting.

I generally play Hell Let Loose, and I compensate the itch to have more overall macro control with micromanagement (and play other maps and environments) with Gates of Hell: Ostfront. Obviously not the same game, but they'll definitely scratch the same itch centers.

[h1]9.5/10[/h1]

If you come across this game, I highly recommend giving it a try. I've seen many players intimidated by this game's controls and end up walking away. What I want to say is don’t be deterred by its so-called "hardcore" label, the game is quite intuitive and user-friendly if you give it a sincere try. It deserves to be enjoyed by a much wider audience.

Let's not be afraid to say it – the best RTS of its kind on the market. In a certain sense, it's almost without competition if you're looking for realistic gameplay in the theater of World War II, since Sudden Strike 4 is just okay, Blitzkrieg 3 is bland as lukewarm tap water at its best moments, Company of Heroes 3 hasn't had much of an idea for itself since launch day, and Men of War II played a game against itself that it knows how to play and lost by mutual walkover, but that's another topic altogether.

What you can love it for…

Unbelievable attention to detail – from uniforms, vehicles, weapon mechanics to the prepared maps.

Absolutely extraordinary and unprecedented ability to perform epic actions on the battlefield. I don't know of another game of this type where you can select a single soldier who picks up a rocket launcher from a fallen enemy to flank an enemy tank from behind, hit it just right to set the ammo compartment on fire, leading to a turret-tossing spectacle where the turret crashes into a building, collapsing part of it and killing two enemy soldiers… nope, I just don't know of any.

The complexity of everything we do: manage ammo, position units to the centimeter for optimal visibility, every battle is a challenge, every clash requires an individual approach, and sometimes you end up playing 5D chess with a well-placed and covered anti-tank gun if you don't have the right countermeasures.

Co-op with another fan of the topic is a bullseye.

…and what to think twice about

Uneven AI – unfortunately, both enemy and ally AI can be inconsistent, especially in conquest mode. They attack incoherently, defend clumsily, and sometimes feel like "spicy" shooting range dummies. It's not a total disaster and can surprise you at times, but it's an area where the developers still have work to do.

Despite everything, a fairly high entry barrier, especially if you're not a fan of micromanagement.

The full price with DLCs is a bit off-putting, but I can't say I regret the purchase (if someone wants to test if this type of game is for them, it's worth grabbing the original – Men of War: Assault Squad 2, which - on sale - costs less than a kebab).

The rest is silence and depends on the player's preferences. No doubt it's a product aimed at a specific target audience, and if you're in it, you can sink many hours here.

This game is an absolute masterpiece!

I play almost exclusively Dynamic Conquest, some of these features I mention don't apply as much in multiplayer.

You can micromanage inventories and take direct control of every individual unit on the field. Not only that, but they will be in every battle until they die or you dismiss them. Every person has a name. I actually care to keep everyone alive through every battle unlike other games where you just spawn more nameless pawns out of a barracks to send to the slaughter.

Tank warfare has been meticulously crafted. I never cared for tank battles in games until now. Armor is thicker/thinner at certain points, the size/type of munitions will play a major role in the outcome, and your tanks have actual crewmembers rather than it just being a lifeless hunk of metal. The tracks/engine can get damaged, leaving the tank stranded and vulnerable to molotovs, anti-tank grenades, etc. You'll have to make quick decisions such as choosing to evacuate your crew and have them run to safety while hoping they don't get mowed down by machine guns. 

Those are two of my favorite points but there is so much more.

There is still so much untapped potential in this game, and I hope they continue to work on this for years to come.

[h1]Great RTS, But the AI will make you uninstall[/h1]

This is probably the best RTS in its genre. The [b]attention to details[/b] is amazing, the [b]atmosphere[/b] and historical accuracy you feel like you're really there. It feels great to play, [i]up until[/i] it doesn't.

[h2]Why I'm so frustrated[/h2]

The game gets ruined by an [b]immense amount of AI spamming[/b] in some missions. It gets to the point where it's literally unplayable. Strategy doesn't matter when the enemy gets infinite units, as the game just turns into a meatgrinder where you focus on endlessly killing AI tanks and hoping yours survive.

To make things even worse, sometimes your own AI just picks a weird path and runs straight into the enemy for no reason. So you're fighting an enemy that's a perfect micromanager, while also trying to stop your own guys from getting themselves killed like idiots. It's frustrating as hell.

A lot of these missions are likely meant for co-op, but [b]you can't host your DLC missions for friends who don't own them[/b]. Since the game's missions are mostly locked behind DLCs, I was forced to play them alone. I can micromanage a few squads, but trying to defend a huge area against an overwhelming amount of AI attacking you (on a mission where you are the one supposed to attack) makes me uninstall this game.

And when the AI starts spamming, the performance starts to show some cracks. It all just becomes a huge, laggy mess.

[h1]Final verdict[/h1]

Basically a hit-and-miss game.

[b]BUY THIS FOR CO-OP[/b], if your friend has enough money to buy all the same DLCs.

[b]AVOID THIS FOR SINGLEPLAYER[/b], unless you're ready to waste hours battling an AI that's 100 times better at micromanaging crap than you are. I really liked this game, but I've got enough of AI spamming bullshit.

Call to Arms: Gates of Hell: Ost Front is an interesting combination of tactical level RTS and first-person shooter set during WW2 on the East Front, 1941-45. Graphics are quite good and the game offers a wide variety of equipment from both German & Soviet arsenals. The sim/FPS shooter aspect is an engaging high point. At times, combat can convey a real feel for the chaos of battle. However, numerous design flaws, & unnecessary micromanagement spoil what could be a potentially great game. 

GoH possesses an incredible amount of detail and control over individual units (particularly infantry); however, these detailed features end up causing unneeded over-complexity which leads to constant micromanagement. If the game had some decent AI that allows you to give general orders to groups of units it wouldn’t be a problem; but other than some basic defensive commands for individual units, you have no help with this respect. 

Additionally, there is little comprehensive feedback indicating what you’ve done once you’ve given orders. Location markers that note your troops destination only appear if you’re clicked onto a unit, and there’s nothing to affirm whether your unit is positively aiming at an enemy target. So you’re largely left trying to memorize what you’ve targeted & where you’ve sent numerous units. Pausing the game helps little, since this feature limits many of your unit’s actions. 

A lack of a decent battlefield overview is another major defect. The mini-map is a muddied cluster of symbols that gives inaccurate locations and a highly restricted camera narrows your overall map view down to a small segment of the battlefield. So it’s hard to get a comprehensive view of combat during battle. Frequently you’ll find yourself unable to locate enemy units at critical times when your troops are being annihilated.

On top of this, virtually all battles require some sort of needless preparation in order to complete objectives. This primarily amounts to manually supplying each infantryman with special weapons, reorganizing numerous infantry squads, hastily planting mines, or hectically sending your units to defensive locations around the map just before the enemy arrives. It’s quite time consuming and, frankly, annoying. At the very least, the game should have some sort of set up phase that allowed the player to equip & place his units on the map before the battle begins. 

So in the end, you find yourself spending much more time trying to organize, equip and command your troops than attending to the enemies attacks. When you do get around to engaging the enemy, you’ll find yourself hyper-focused on small areas of the enemy’s assault while all other parts of the map are completely ignored. In larger battles, ones where many dozens of units are involved, you’ll simply be overwhelmed by everything that’s happening. 

So, overall, Gates of Hell is a mixed-bag. It can be genuinely entertaining, but unfortunately far too frequently, it’s just an aggravation to play.
